channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Married to an Undocumented Immigrant? You May Not Get a Stimulus Check.
item.description: Undocumented immigrants are ineligible for federal payments to help families during the coronavirus pandemic. So are their spouses, even if they are U.S. citizens.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Dickerson
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: Jonny Arenas, 41, holds hands with his husband in Seattle. Mr. Arenas immigrated from Mexico and his husband is an American citizen.

item.title: Coronavirus Closed Campuses, So College Tours Moved Online
item.description: Colleges are ghost towns, but officials are trying to reach prospective students with virtual visits and Zoom meetings. Can they replicate that face-to-face feeling?
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey
item.media:description: When the Yale University campus closed in March, the admissions team moved quickly to shift its programming online.

item.title: Coronavirus Likely to Keep Schools Shut, Despite Trump's Wishes
item.description: Most districts have no plans to end online lessons soon, and reopening will bring significant changes, educators say.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler, Erica L. Green and Dana Goldstein
item.media:description: An empty playground at Kent Middle School in Kentfield, Calif. Only a few states are considering the possibility of reopening schools before the summer break.

item.title: What We Know About the Shooting Death of Ahmaud Arbery
item.description: Mr. Arbery, a 25-year-old black man, was chased by armed white residents of a South Georgia neighborhood. He was shot dead during a confrontation.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset
item.media:description: Homes in Glynn County, Ga., where Ahmaud Arbery lived and was killed.

item.title: Justin Amash Moves Toward a Third-Party Bid for President
item.description: Mr. Amash, an independent congressman from Michigan who left the Republican Party last year, said he was exploring running as a Libertarian, adding new volatility to the race.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Justin Amash of Michigan during a town hall event in Grand Rapids, Mich., in May 2019.

item.title: Mfume to Return to Congress, Succeeding Elijah Cummings
item.description: He first held the seat from 1987 to 1996 until he left to serve as president of the N.A.A.C.P. and was replaced by Mr. Cummings, who died in October.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:description: Kweisi Mfume, center, with his wife, Tiffany, left, in Baltimore in February, after winning the Democratic nomination for the congressional seat to represent Baltimore.

item.title: James Beggs, 94, Is Dead; NASA Chief Championed Space Shuttle
item.description: He was on leave during the Challenger disaster in 1986 and resigned shortly after what critics called a leadership vacuum.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: Digital Ad Strategy Shows Impact on Voters’ Views of Trump
item.description: Here’s a deeper look at how the Barometer team at Acronym is testing the impact of its Facebook ads.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti

item.title: Senate Republicans to Push Ahead on Judges Over Democratic Objections
item.description: The Judiciary Committee is poised to consider the nomination of a McConnell protégé to an influential appeals court, while Democrats say the focus should be on the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:description: “As soon as we get back in session, we’ll start confirming judges again,” Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, said last week.

item.title: Biggest Mall Operator in U.S. Plans to Reopen 49 of Them
item.description: In a memo, Simon Property Group laid out how it planned to open the properties in 10 states between Friday and Monday.
item.dc:creator: Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery
item.media:description: A closed mall owned by Simon Property Group in Schaumburg, Ill., outside Chicago.

item.title: May Congress Sue the Executive Branch? Court Hears Cases on Subpoena and Border Wall
item.description: A federal appeals court took up two cases testing whether the House can challenge a president in court.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: An appeals court in Washington heard two cases involving disputes between the House and President Trump.

item.title: N.Y. Building Sites Reopen, Carefully, in Sign of Life Gearing Back Up
item.description: More than 5,200 construction projects have reopened in New York City, offering a glimpse of new routines in postpandemic workplaces.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Haag
item.category: Building and Construction Trade Council of Greater New York
item.media:credit: Gregg Vigliotti for The New York Times
item.media:description: At construction sites that are open, workers are getting their temperature taken before their shift begins.

item.title: Man Charged With Hate Crime in Suspected Arson at Islamic Center
item.description: Nicholas Proffitt pleaded guilty to a hate crime after throwing rocks at the Islamic center in Cape Girardeau, Mo., in 2009. Eleven years later he returned to set the building on fire, the police say.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:credit: Jacob Wiegand/The Southeast Missourian, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Islamic Center of Cape Girardeau was condemned by the city after the fire last week, the police said.

item.title: How the Spanish Flu Almost Upended Women's Suffrage
item.description: Canceled rallies. A looming election. A stretched healthcare system with a predominantly female face. Women’s frustrations then resonate loud and clear today.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:description: The interior of Red Cross House at U.S. General Hospital #16 is seen during the 1918 Spanish Flu pandemic in New Haven, Conn. in 1919.

item.title: DeVos Decides Against Special Education Waivers During the Pandemic
item.description: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos has informed Congress that she will not seek to grant waivers from special education requirements under federal law.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: “With ingenuity, innovation and grit, I know this nation’s educators and schools can continue to faithfully educate every one of its students,” Education Secretary Betsy DeVos said.

item.title: Under Pressure, House Leaders Scrap Plans for Speedy Return to the Capitol
item.description: With no legislative work scheduled, some rank-and-file lawmakers protested and the Capitol physician warned that a return to Washington carried health risks.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane and Nicholas Fandos
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: Representative Steny H. Hoyer, the majority leader, said lawmakers hoped to return once they were ready to consider another pandemic relief package.

item.title: May the Fourth Be With Disney (Terms and Conditions Apply)
item.description: When Disney asked “Star Wars” fans to share their favorite memories of the franchise using the hashtag #MayThe4th, it said responses would fall under its terms of use agreement. Social media users were scathing.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: “Star Wars” fans around the world informally celebrate the series on May 4. Disney’s effort to collect memories for the occasion did not go as planned.

item.title: The Pentagon Released U.F.O. Videos. Don’t Hold Your Breath for a Breakthrough.
item.description: On Monday, the Department of Defense formally released three Navy videos that contain “unidentified aerial phenomena.” Enthusiasts were encouraged, though there was nothing new.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Department of Defense, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: JetBlue Is the First Major U.S. Airline to Require Masks for Passengers
item.description: The airline will require all passengers to wear a face covering from the beginning to the end of their trip. The policy takes effect Monday.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: JetBlue will require passengers to cover their mouths and noses at check-in, boarding and for the duration of their flight.

item.title: Watch Live: Hillary Clinton Endorses Joe Biden for President
item.description: The announcement by the 2016 Democratic presidential nominee follows ones from Barack Obama, Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren as the party tries to show its unity.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer, Maggie Astor and Sydney Ember
item.media:description: With an expected endorsement of Joseph R. Biden Jr., Hillary Clinton is the latest party leader to try to make a case for returning the White House to Democratic hands in November.

item.title: Former Aides to Bernie Sanders Form a Super PAC to Support Joe Biden
item.description: Mr. Sanders’s 2016 campaign manager and another architect of the 2016 bid are joining together in an effort to rally progressive support for the former vice president ahead of the November election.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.category: Future To Believe In PAC (Political Organization)
item.media:description: Jeff Weaver, a former top aide and campaign manager for Senator Bernie Sanders, is helping form a new super PAC to support Joe Biden’s presidential bid.

item.title: Nearly 2 Million Chickens Killed as Poultry Workers Are Sidelined
item.description: An industry group said the chickens were “depopulated” at farms in Delaware and Maryland because of staffing challenges related to the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chicken supplies were running low at a grocery store in Brenham, Texas, last month.

item.title: Making Theater Essential, Digitally
item.description: The Homebound Project convenes 50 actors and playwrights to raise money for a project combating childhood hunger.
item.dc:creator: Devi Lockwood
item.media:credit: Daniel Dorsa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Catya McMullen, a playwright, who helped to create the Homebound Project along with the stage director Jenna Worsham.

item.title: Coronavirus and Race: Black and Latino People Are California's Most Vulnerable
item.description: Tuesday: Dr. Sonia Angell, the state’s public health director, discusses troubling trends. Also: A remembrance of a Riverside County deputy.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: A surfer made his way into the waves as a man walked his dog on Monday in San Diego. The city opened its beaches to surfing, running and walking, but sitting at the beach remains prohibited.

item.title: Trump’s Response to Virus Reflects a Long Disregard for Science
item.description: The president’s Covid-19 response has extended the administration’s longstanding practice of undermining scientific expertise for political purposes.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Brad Plumer
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump arrived at the White House daily coronavirus briefing this month.

item.title: On Politics: How Available Is Virus Aid, Really?
item.description: Rising complaints from governors, and some Supreme Court news: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: Coronavirus, Texas, Paycheck Protection Program: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford
item.media:credit: Rachel Woolf for The New York Times
item.media:description: A tattoo parlor in Greeley, Colo., on Monday. States are beginning to reopen a patchwork of businesses.

item.title: Coronavirus Live News Updates
item.description: School officials balk at calls for returning to classrooms this spring. The number of known U.S. cases passed 1 million. Vice President Mike Pence visited the Mayo Clinic without a face mask.

item.title: Women at a Marine Boot Camp Represent an Identity Crisis for the Corps
item.description: Keeping men and women in separate platoons during recruit training is the last stand for the Marine Corps, which has been slow to move toward gender integration.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Hilary Swift
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island (SC)
item.media:description: Recruits at Parris Island shouted “no brass, no trash, no live rounds” while getting checked for weapons after a drill.

item.title: Rhode Island Pushes Aggressive Testing, a Move That Could Ease Reopening
item.description: The state has seen a rise in cases of the coronavirus, in part, experts say, because it is testing more than many states.
item.dc:creator: Michael Powell
item.media:description: Rhode Island’s first walk-up coronavirus testing site opened last week, in Providence.
